news_header: German voters will decide on February 23 who will lead their next government, with Friedrich Merz's conservative Christian Democrats favored to become the largest party.
news_original_title: Who's who in German elections and why this vote is important
news_text: Key issues include immigration control and reviving the economy, especially after a series of deadly attacks that have increased pressure on mainstream parties to reform immigration policies. Merz, a pro-business conservative, promises stricter immigration rules and economic reforms. Olaf Scholz, the current chancellor, faces challenges due to his unpopular coalition and economic struggles. Other candidates include Alice Weidel from the far-right AfD, who has gained popularity among young voters. The election will determine the composition of the Bundestag, with significant changes in voting rules and a reduction in seats.
